• Representing the architectures of both the ANN-based building model and the MP-enabled ANN model with explicit sets of linear and nonlinear equations, which enable the application of a deterministic solver.

• Applying the online supervised learning to both the ANN-based building model and the MP-enabled ANN model, which facilitates practical implementation of the data-driven DR and retail-pricing strategies.

As in the case of the ANN-based building model, the trained ANN is represented using explicit equations with parameter set M. The CBO or end-users can provide M to the DSO as a condition of participating in the DR program, as they submit the physics-based model parameters and operational constraints of the HVAC systems and building thermal zones in conventional strategies [12,18].

In other words, the more historical data there are available for various conditions of HVAC system operation and building thermal environment, the higher the accuracy of the ANN-based building model in reflecting the indoor temperature variations in response to changes in the HVAC load demand and building thermal environment.

In other words, given Copt t , the profiles of Popt t predicted using the MP-enabled ANN and corresponding Tt estimated using the ANN-based building model become similar to those obtained by solving the DR optimization problem.

3 summarizes the online-learning steps for the ANN-based building model and the MP-enabled ANN as follows: Step 1) The proposed strategy is initiated with a moderate level of performance, resulting from the limited size and variability of the initial training data and hence the rather inaccurate ANN models.

3 Price-based DR using the ANN-based building model 3.1 ANN-based building thermal model An ANN-based data-driven model is implemented to reflect the thermal dynamics of a single-zone building, specifically, to estimate Tt for Pt during the time period from t–NAP to t, given Et over the period from t–NAE to t. In general, Tt at the current time is affected by the past values of Pt and Et , due to the large thermal capacity inherent in the building structure.

3.2 Optimization problem formulation for price-based DR Using the ANN-based thermal dynamic model (i.e., (2)–(6)), optimal day-ahead scheduling of the HVAC load demand Pt can be achieved by solving the DR optimization problem S1: S1: CBO’s DR using the ANN-based building model (7) arg min P t J C = ∑ t = 1 N T C t · P t , subject to • Constraints on the physical conditions Tt and Pt (8) T min t ⩽ T t ⩽ T max t , ∀ t , (9) P min ⩽ P t ⩽ P max , ∀ t , (10) R N ⩽ P t - P t - Δ t / Δ t ⩽ R P , ∀ t , • Constraints on the relations among Tt, Pt, and Et of the ANN (11) n Ak t - ∑ i ∈ X AP N AP + 1 H Aki x Ai t - ∑ i ∈ X AZ N AZ H Aki x Ai t = ∑ i ∈ X AE N AE + 2 H Aki x Ai t + d Ak , ∀ i , ∀ k , ∀ t , and (3)–(6), • Constraints on the current and time-delayed inputs of the ANN (12) α Aj t = E t - ( j - 2 ) Δ t , ∀ j ⩾ 2 , t ⩾ j Δ t , (13) α Aj t = E pre ( N T + ( t - ( j - 2 ) Δ t ) ) , ∀ j ⩾ 2 , t ⩽ ( j - 1 ) Δ t , (14) β Al t = P t - ( l - 1 ) Δ t , ∀ l , t ⩾ l Δ t , (15) β Al t = P pre ( N T + ( t - ( l - 1 ) Δ t ) ) , ∀ l , t ⩽ ( l - 1 ) Δ t , (16) γ Af t = T t - f Δ t , ∀ f , t ⩾ ( f + 1 ) Δ t , (17) γ Af t = T pre ( N T + ( t - f Δ t ) ) , ∀ f , t ⩽ f Δ t , (18) X Ai t ∈ t , α Aj = 2 t , · · · , α Aj = ( N AE + 2 ) t , β Al = 1 t , · · · , β Al = ( N AP + 1 ) t , γ Af = 1 t , · · · , γ Af = N Z t , ∀ i , ∀ t .
Note that (20)–(29) represent the explicit replication of the MP-enabled ANN, as in (3)–(18) for the ANN-based building model.

Due to the explicit expressions of the ANN-based building model and the MP-enabled ANN, an off-the-shelf nonlinear programming solver can be applied to S1 and S2, ensuring the near-global optimality of the solutions.

The ANN-based thermal model and the MP-enabled ANN were trained initially with the datasets of [t, Et , Tt , Pt , Ct ], whose size was set to 1200 (i.e., 50 days) with respect to time, and updated repeatedly via online learning, as the new profiles of [Et , Tt , Pt , Ct ] were obtained from S1 and S2.

9 a shows the results of e(T) when online learning of the ANN-based building model was performed daily over 190 days; the parameter set A was updated at the end of each scheduling time period (i.e., t = NT ).
Moreover, the ANN-based building model was trained online with the new building operating data obtained over a period of 190 days.

5.3 Comparison between the proposed and ideal DR strategies Using the ANN-based building model, S1 was solved to determine the optimal HVAC load schedule for the 24-h profiles of Ct and Tx t , shown in Fig.

11c shows the optimal profile of Pt (i.e., the blue line) for the proposed DR strategy using the ANN-based building model in comparison to that (i.e., the red line) for the ideal DR strategy using the fully informed physics-based building model.
It is also possible that the marginal error in the ANN-based building model is reflected in the optimal profiles of Pt and Tt , although the ANN-based model is fairly accurate, as shown in Fig.
The main features of the proposed strategy are as follows: • An ANN-based building model is implemented to reflect a building’s thermal response to HVAC system operation.

Variables Ct retail electricity price at time t gA t , gM hvt normalized output for ANN-based modeling and MP of HVAC unit h at DN bus v at time t JC , JD electricity cost of price-sensitive HVAC unit and profit of DSO mAk t , mMk hvt output of activation function for the k th hidden neuron for ANN-based modeling and MP of HVAC unit h at DN bus v at time t nAk t , nMk hvt output of k th hidden neuron for ANN-based modeling and MP of HVAC unit h at DN bus v at time t Pt , Phvt input power of price-sensitive HVAC unit h at DN bus v at time t Po vt , Po vt total power input of price-sensitive and price-inelastic HVAC units at bus v at time t Tt indoor temperature at time t Tm t measured indoor temperature for optimal Pt XAi t , XMi hvt i th input for ANN-based modeling and MP of HVAC unit h at DN bus v at time t xAi t , xMi hvt normalized values of XAi t and XMi hvt ΔVn t voltage variation matrix for DN bus n at time t αAj t , βAl t , γAf t environmental factors, power inputs, and indoor temperatures for ANN-based modeling at time t αMj hvt , βMl hvt , ωMq hvt environmental factors, power inputs, and retail electricity prices for ANN-based MP of HVAC unit h at DN bus v 1 Introduction Heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems represent more than 35% of the electricity usage of commercial buildings, accounting for approximately 13% of the electricity consumption in the United States in 2017 [1].

• Representing the architectures of both the ANN-based building model and the MP-enabled ANN model with explicit sets of linear and nonlinear equations, which enable the application of a deterministic solver.

• Applying the online supervised learning to both the ANN-based building model and the MP-enabled ANN model, which facilitates practical implementation of the data-driven DR and retail-pricing strategies.

As in the case of the ANN-based building model, the trained ANN is represented using explicit equations with parameter set M. The CBO or end-users can provide M to the DSO as a condition of participating in the DR program, as they submit the physics-based model parameters and operational constraints of the HVAC systems and building thermal zones in conventional strategies [12,18].

In other words, the more historical data there are available for various conditions of HVAC system operation and building thermal environment, the higher the accuracy of the ANN-based building model in reflecting the indoor temperature variations in response to changes in the HVAC load demand and building thermal environment.

In other words, given Copt t , the profiles of Popt t predicted using the MP-enabled ANN and corresponding Tt estimated using the ANN-based building model become similar to those obtained by solving the DR optimization problem.

3 summarizes the online-learning steps for the ANN-based building model and the MP-enabled ANN as follows: Step 1) The proposed strategy is initiated with a moderate level of performance, resulting from the limited size and variability of the initial training data and hence the rather inaccurate ANN models.

3 Price-based DR using the ANN-based building model 3.1 ANN-based building thermal model An ANN-based data-driven model is implemented to reflect the thermal dynamics of a single-zone building, specifically, to estimate Tt for Pt during the time period from t–NAP to t, given Et over the period from t–NAE to t. In general, Tt at the current time is affected by the past values of Pt and Et , due to the large thermal capacity inherent in the building structure.

3.2 Optimization problem formulation for price-based DR Using the ANN-based thermal dynamic model (i.e., (2)–(6)), optimal day-ahead scheduling of the HVAC load demand Pt can be achieved by solving the DR optimization problem S1: S1: CBO’s DR using the ANN-based building model (7) arg min P t J C = ∑ t = 1 N T C t · P t , subject to • Constraints on the physical conditions Tt and Pt (8) T min t ⩽ T t ⩽ T max t , ∀ t , (9) P min ⩽ P t ⩽ P max , ∀ t , (10) R N ⩽ P t - P t - Δ t / Δ t ⩽ R P , ∀ t , • Constraints on the relations among Tt, Pt, and Et of the ANN (11) n Ak t - ∑ i ∈ X AP N AP + 1 H Aki x Ai t - ∑ i ∈ X AZ N AZ H Aki x Ai t = ∑ i ∈ X AE N AE + 2 H Aki x Ai t + d Ak , ∀ i , ∀ k , ∀ t , and (3)–(6), • Constraints on the current and time-delayed inputs of the ANN (12) α Aj t = E t - ( j - 2 ) Δ t , ∀ j ⩾ 2 , t ⩾ j Δ t , (13) α Aj t = E pre ( N T + ( t - ( j - 2 ) Δ t ) ) , ∀ j ⩾ 2 , t ⩽ ( j - 1 ) Δ t , (14) β Al t = P t - ( l - 1 ) Δ t , ∀ l , t ⩾ l Δ t , (15) β Al t = P pre ( N T + ( t - ( l - 1 ) Δ t ) ) , ∀ l , t ⩽ ( l - 1 ) Δ t , (16) γ Af t = T t - f Δ t , ∀ f , t ⩾ ( f + 1 ) Δ t , (17) γ Af t = T pre ( N T + ( t - f Δ t ) ) , ∀ f , t ⩽ f Δ t , (18) X Ai t ∈ t , α Aj = 2 t , · · · , α Aj = ( N AE + 2 ) t , β Al = 1 t , · · · , β Al = ( N AP + 1 ) t , γ Af = 1 t , · · · , γ Af = N Z t , ∀ i , ∀ t .
Note that (20)–(29) represent the explicit replication of the MP-enabled ANN, as in (3)–(18) for the ANN-based building model.

Due to the explicit expressions of the ANN-based building model and the MP-enabled ANN, an off-the-shelf nonlinear programming solver can be applied to S1 and S2, ensuring the near-global optimality of the solutions.

The ANN-based thermal model and the MP-enabled ANN were trained initially with the datasets of [t, Et , Tt , Pt , Ct ], whose size was set to 1200 (i.e., 50 days) with respect to time, and updated repeatedly via online learning, as the new profiles of [Et , Tt , Pt , Ct ] were obtained from S1 and S2.

9 a shows the results of e(T) when online learning of the ANN-based building model was performed daily over 190 days; the parameter set A was updated at the end of each scheduling time period (i.e., t = NT ).
Moreover, the ANN-based building model was trained online with the new building operating data obtained over a period of 190 days.

5.3 Comparison between the proposed and ideal DR strategies Using the ANN-based building model, S1 was solved to determine the optimal HVAC load schedule for the 24-h profiles of Ct and Tx t , shown in Fig.

11c shows the optimal profile of Pt (i.e., the blue line) for the proposed DR strategy using the ANN-based building model in comparison to that (i.e., the red line) for the ideal DR strategy using the fully informed physics-based building model.
It is also possible that the marginal error in the ANN-based building model is reflected in the optimal profiles of Pt and Tt , although the ANN-based model is fairly accurate, as shown in Fig.
The main features of the proposed strategy are as follows: • An ANN-based building model is implemented to reflect a building’s thermal response to HVAC system operation.

3 Price-based DR using the ANN-based building model 3.1 ANN-based building thermal model An ANN-based data-driven model is implemented to reflect the thermal dynamics of a single-zone building, specifically, to estimate Tt for Pt during the time period from t–NAP to t, given Et over the period from t–NAE to t. In general, Tt at the current time is affected by the past values of Pt and Et , due to the large thermal capacity inherent in the building structure.

3 Price-based DR using the ANN-based building model 3.1 ANN-based building thermal model An ANN-based data-driven model is implemented to reflect the thermal dynamics of a single-zone building, specifically, to estimate Tt for Pt during the time period from t–NAP to t, given Et over the period from t–NAE to t. In general, Tt at the current time is affected by the past values of Pt and Et , due to the large thermal capacity inherent in the building structure.

9 Online learning results: (a) e(T) and (b) e(P) for the tests of the ANN-based building model and MP-enabled ANN model, respectively.
Recently, online learning has been discussed as a method to mitigate this risk, gradually improving modeling performance with additional data collection.

Therefore, after the initial training, the ANN then undergoes repeated online learning (corresponding to the data flows numbered 2 and 3), as the price-based DR is initiated and new data on the HVAC system operations and indoor temperature variations start to be obtained for various retail price and building environment profiles.
Analogously, the data flows specified by the arrows numbered 8 and 9 are particularly active when online learning is applied to the MP-enabled ANN.
The ANN is then integrated into the DR optimization problem, as discussed in Section 3.2, and applied to online learning.
The set A also can be updated continuously, as the online learning of the ANN is conducted on a daily basis.
5 a shows a simplified schematic diagram of the proposed retail pricing strategy, focusing on the data flows for the online training and application of the MP-enabled ANN.
To mitigate the degradation, the ANN is updated periodically via online learning.

In other words, after the proposed pricing strategy has been initiated with a rather moderate level of performance, online learning is applied to the MP-enabled ANN, as the new profiles of Copt t and Popt t are obtained under various Et (see Fig.

The ANN-based thermal model and the MP-enabled ANN were trained initially with the datasets of [t, Et , Tt , Pt , Ct ], whose size was set to 1200 (i.e., 50 days) with respect to time, and updated repeatedly via online learning, as the new profiles of [Et , Tt , Pt , Ct ] were obtained from S1 and S2.
5.2 Online learning of the ANNs for DR and retail pricing Fig.

9 a shows the results of e(T) when online learning of the ANN-based building model was performed daily over 190 days; the parameter set A was updated at the end of each scheduling time period (i.e., t = NT ).
In general, e(T) increased gradually, indicating improvement in the modeling accuracy, as the CBO continued the online learning after initiating the DR strategy.
9b shows e(P) when the online learning of the MP-enabled ANN model was conducted daily for an additional 190 days, updating the parameter set M every day at t = NT .
This improved the online learning performance of the MP-enabled ANN further.

Noticeable reductions in e(P) were observed occasionally, unlike in the case of e(T); however, it can be seen that e(P) still gradually increased from 0.26 to 0.86 (gradient of 2.2 × 10−3 per day), as the online learning continued.

• As new data are acquired regarding the daily conditions of DN operation and buildings’ environments, the ANN models undergo online learning, improving the modeling accuracy and the scheduling performance.

whitebox: This study formulates a data-driven model with an advanced machine learning algorithm for the accurate building demand prediction and a hybrid advanced controller with short-term prediction for the energy management, which are critical for the promotion of energy flexible buildings.

As the building energy systems in TRNSYS 18 are quite complicated during both modelling and simulation processes, the motivation for the surrogate model is to improve the computational efficiency without sacrificing the accuracy; 3) By driving the surrogate model for the short-term prediction of building energy performances, the predicted control signal was implemented in the real-time energy management system, forming advanced controllers, to enhance the building energy flexibility.

As the building energy systems in TRNSYS 18 are quite complicated during both modelling and simulation processes, the motivation for the surrogate model is to improve the computational efficiency without sacrificing the accuracy; 3) By driving the surrogate model for the short-term prediction of building energy performances, the predicted control signal was implemented in the real-time energy management system, forming advanced controllers, to enhance the building energy flexibility.
Furthermore, by implementing the hybrid controller in the energy management system, the peak power of the building energy demand is significantly reduced to 382.8 kW, as shown in Fig.
10, the time-duration of the peak power is significantly reduced by implementing the hybrid controller in the energy management system.

4) By implementing the surrogate model in the building energy management, the developed hybrid controller is more technically competitive than other controllers in terms of fully utilising the building energy flexibility: 27% surplus renewable electricity can be the flexible forced electricity and 55% electric demand can be covered by the forced electricity at the renewable surplus period.

ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) systems [2].
With this setting, the MPC controller puts emphasis on keeping indoor PMV close to thermal neutrality (PMV = 0) as it seeks to minimize cooling energy consumption.
The objectives of the MPC system are to minimize cooling energy consumption and chase the best thermal comfort, as shown in Eq.

Keywords Model Predictive Control (MPC) Machine-learning (ML) Artificial Neural Network (ANN) Air Conditioning and Mechanical Ventilation (ACMV) Building Automation and Control (BAC) Nomenclature Abbreviations ACMV Air Conditioning and Mechanical Ventilation AHU Air-Handling Unit ANN Artificial Neural Network BAC Building Automation and Control BMS Building Management Systems COP Coefficient of Performance ESM Exhaustive Search Method FA Firefly Algorithm FAD Fresh Air Damper FCU Fan Coil Unit GA Genetic Algorithm HVAC Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning I/O Inputs/Outputs LED Light-Emitting-Diode LM Levenberg-Marquardt LT Lecture Theatre 3 MAE Mean Absolute Error ML Machine Learning MLP Multi-Layer Perceptron MPC Model Predictive Control NARX Nonlinear Autoregressive Exogenous NTU Nanyang Technological University PID Proportional–Integral–Derivative PMV Predicted Mean Vote PSO Particle Swarm Optimization RAD Return Air Damper RH Relative Humidity RTP Research Techno Plaza SQP Subsequent Quadratic Programming THPL Temperature-Humidity-Pressure-Lux VAV Variable Air Volume VSD Variable Speed Drive Symbols PMV ^ Normalized PMV index Q ^ Normalized cooling power m ̇ Mass flow rate (kg/s) C CO2 concentration (m3/m3) d Number of delay time steps f() Function G Volume flow rate (m3/s) hod Hour of day J Objective N Prediction horizon os Operation status Q Heat flow rate (W) S CO2 generation rate per person (m3/s) t Time (s) T Temperature (oC) u Input W Penalty factor y Output ε Slack variable ψ Humidity ratio (kg/kg) Subscripts cw Chilled water cwr Chilled water return cws Chilled water supply g Globe k Index of time steps max Maximum min Minimum mr Mean radiant PMV Predicted mean vote ref Reference sa Supply air z Thermal zone 1 Introduction The building sector accounts for 40% of the world’s total primary energy consumption [1] and more than 50% of building energy consumption is attributed to heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) systems [2].
With this setting, the MPC controller puts emphasis on keeping indoor PMV close to thermal neutrality (PMV = 0) as it seeks to minimize cooling energy consumption.
The objectives of the MPC system are to minimize cooling energy consumption and chase the best thermal comfort, as shown in Eq.

This energy saving is achieved by taking advantage of thermal comfort knowledge and model-based optimization feature of the MPC system to pursue thermal neutrality with minimum cooling energy consumption.

blackbox: 1 An overview of the approach for developing the MPC system with an adaptive ML-based building model.

The system features an adaptive machine-learning-based building dynamics modelling scheme that updates the building model regularly using online building operation data through a dynamic artificial neural network with a nonlinear autoregressive exogenous structure.

In contrast, ML is a data-driven modelling approach that constructs a model merely based on data, which means a ML-based building model could predict building dynamics without knowing the physics and information of the building [23].

[29] implemented a MPC controller with an artificial neural network (ANN)-based building model in a public building to control its HVAC system for optimizing indoor thermal comfort and energy consumption.

[31] implemented a MPC controller with a data-driven building model in an HVAC test facility to optimize HVAC energy efficiency and reported an average of 1.5 MWh of energy savings as compared to the original control.
Most previous studies on MPC with a ML-based building model reported in the literature are based on simulations.

[32] developed a MPC controller using a random-forest-based building model, which was demonstrated by simulations to have comparable performance with respect to a MPC with a perfectly-known physics-based building model.
[33] employed an ANN-based airport building model to evaluate a MPC controller with a physics-based building model.
[34] developed a MPC controller for hybrid ventilation buildings using an ANN-based building model.
[35] developed a MPC controller using an ANN-based building model for scheduling heating set points in a building.
[36] developed a MPC controller for a residential building using an ANN-based building model and an energy saving capacity of 6–73% was found in their simulations.
Experimental studies that could evaluate the performance of MPC with a ML-based building model covering a substantially long period of time are still lacking.

A solution to these challenges is to develop a self-adaptive ML-based building model that exploits online building operation data to update the building model continuously as the building is controlled by MPC in real-time.
This study aims to develop a MPC system using a self-adaptive ML-based building model to manage ACMV systems for optimal energy efficiency and indoor thermal comfort.

The developed MPC system using a ML-based building model is implemented in two real building testbeds (an office and a lecture theatre) that are on the campus of Nanyang Technological University (NTU) in Singapore.
The historical building operation data is used to construct and train an initial building model using ANN, which is chosen due to its high accuracy to model nonlinear systems [36].
The ANN-based initial building model is then used to formulate an initial MPC controller.
This new data set is collected and fed back to the database at each control interval for adaptation of the ANN-based building model periodically at a time interval (‘model adaption interval’).

Once the ANN-based building model is updated by adaptation, a new MPC controller is formulated automatically using the updated model and performs real-time control during the next model adaption cycle.

In this study, the proposed MPC system with an adaptive ML-based building model is developed and experimentally implemented in two single-zone testbeds, an office room and a lecture theatre, as described in Chapters 3 and 4.

However, in a previous study [56] using physics-based building model for MPC, it was found that adding the model adaptation feature in the MPC controller helped in improving indoor thermal comfort without causing extra cooling energy consumption.

It could be inferred that, with the advantages in model prediction shown above, the addition of model adaption to the ML-based building model could improve MPC controller in thermal comfort performance.

In the previous study [17], MPC with a physics-based building model maintained the indoor PMV close to thermal neutrality with an average PMV of −0.09 and achieved 18% of energy savings as compared to the original BMS.
The test of the MPC with a physics-based building model was conducted during January–March 2019 (monsoon season).
The test of the MPC with a ML-based building model in current study was conducted during August–September 2019 (inter-monsoon season).

The physics-based building model requires detailed building information (e.g., dimensions and materials of building structure and specifications of building systems) to construct since it is based on the heat and mass transfer equations of the building structures and systems.
The development of a physics-based building model requires high level of expertise in building physics and is usually tedious and time-consuming, often takes up months to do.
For instance, the time consumed to develop the physics-based building model of LT in [17] was around six months.

In contrast, as demonstrated through the current study, training of ML-based building model and collection of building operation data by BMS for the training could be achieved through fully automated processes.
Much less human effort, including time, and expertise, is required to develop a MPC system using ML-based building model.
For instance, the time consumed to develop the ML-based building model for the same LT in this study was around one week.

Despite its drawback as discussed above, the physics-based modelling approach does not require building operation data and, thus, the physics-based building model could be developed during the design and construction phases of new buildings.

Although a MPC with a physics-based building dynamics model was also implemented in the same LT testbed in a prior study [19], its control performance in terms of energy efficiency and thermal comfort cannot be compared the MPC with a ML-based building model developed in the current study as the two MPC are implemented in different season periods that caused larger differences in the external and internal heat loads.

7 Conclusion This paper presented the development, implementation, experimental testing and performance analysis of a proposed model predictive control system with an adaptive machine-learning-based building model for building automation and control applications.

Due to its working principle, the accuracy of the building model in predicting the future evolution of building conditions is critically important to MPC of buildings.

A solution to these challenges is to develop a self-adaptive ML-based building model that exploits online building operation data to update the building model continuously as the building is controlled by MPC in real-time.
This study aims to develop a MPC system using a self-adaptive ML-based building model to manage ACMV systems for optimal energy efficiency and indoor thermal comfort.

The developed MPC system using a ML-based building model is implemented in two real building testbeds (an office and a lecture theatre) that are on the campus of Nanyang Technological University (NTU) in Singapore.

2.2 Building modelling To achieve optimal energy efficiency and thermal comfort, the building model should be able to capture the dynamics of building physics and to estimate indoor thermal comfort.

Thus, the building model includes two sub-models: (1) a building dynamics model that predicts indoor conditions such as air temperature, humidity and globe temperature with inputs of internal loads, weather conditions and cooling power of ACMV systems and, (2) a thermal comfort model to estimate indoor thermal comfort index with inputs of indoor conditions.
The ESM optimizer evaluates the PMV result of each candidate using the building model (building dynamics and thermal comfort models).

A combined air temperature-relative humidity (RH) sensor and an airflow sensor are installed in the supply air duct leading to the VAV box for real-time monitoring of cooling power supplied to the office.
Another combined air temperature-RH sensor is installed on the meeting table for real-time monitoring of room conditions.
The above-mentioned sensors are connected to an inputs/outputs (I/O) device and the readings are passed to the MPC system in real-time.
As the sensor readings of the thermal comfort measurement device are stored in its data logger offline, there is no real-time feedback of the globe temperature to the MPC controller.

In real-time control, the ACMV model can be adapted at each time step with measured flowrates of fresh air and return air.

If the MPC is implemented on other BMS servers, it is still possible for the developed MPC to perform real-time control as long as the CPU time consumption per optimization is less than the control interval (120 s).
Combining with the forward prediction and real-time multi-objective optimisation capabilities, MPC is shown to take advantage of the full potential of DOAS-assisted SSLC system.

A real-time optimization scheme with a multi-objective cost function is implemented which optimizes both cooling energy efficiency and indoor thermal comfort while maintaining indoor PMV and humidity within required ranges.

reinforcement_learning: Mason and Grijalva (2019) [26] reviewed the application of reinforcement learning for building energy management, including HVAC, water heater, appliances, lighting, photovoltaics (PV), batteries and the electrical grid.

The reason behind this trend is researchers gradually realized an explicitly represented policy function π θ a t | s t could help to transfer the knowledge learned from one building to another, i.e., facilitate transfer learning.
Therefore, increasingly studies are starting to explore the possibility of using policy gradient [32] or actor-critic [35] methods to facilitate transfer learning.
Actor-critic and policy gradient approaches have become more frequently used since 2017 due to their ability to facilitate transfer learning.

Significant barriers limiting the applications of RL controller for real building controls include (1) the training process is time-consuming and data-demanding, (2) the security of controls needs to be addressed, i.e., making sure the RL controller would not mess up the building controls, especially during the training stage, (3) it is yet unknown how to implement the transfer learning so that controllers trained by a small number of buildings could be generalized and used for other buildings, and (4) a data-rich, open-sourced, and interoperable virtual testbed is needed to facilitate cross-study validations and benchmarking of performance of RL controllers.
[26] Mason K, Grijalva S. A review of reinforcement learning for autonomous building energy management.

energy_use|thermal_comfort: For the occupants in the first set, the thermal-comfort-sensitivity-based approach revealed the best overall performance despite its relatively higher energy use.

Given the differences in occupant behavior (as they might perceive comfort differently and react to variations of temperature differently), the personal differences in decision-making processes with regard to the tradeoff between energy use and comfort (i.e., adaptive behavior) could also be influential in the energy efficiency of HVAC systems.

The results showed that the occupants’ thermal comfort characteristics and the number of occupants per thermal zone are the most impactful parameters in shaping the energy use distributions and determining the energy saving potentials of comfort-driven control.

online_learning_evidence: In [25], an MPC based on the EnergyPlus building simulator is developed, which is limited to a look ahead horizon of one-time step for real-time operation.

This policy is typically approximated by a neural network and is suitable for real-time implementation due to its flexibility to be precomputed on a powerful computer, shrunk down, and implemented on a smaller and less powerful discrete controller.

Eventually, when the Q-learning agent is deployed in production, real-time performance data can be used to update the BCNNs and at the same time the Q-learning agent, allowing the system to learn autonomously.

energy_use|thermal_comfort: Therefore, researchers and practitioners have been actively pursuing control methods for HVAC systems that are capable of minimizing energy consumption while improving the indoor environment quality (IEQ) for occupants, including thermal comfort and indoor air quality [3,4,38,39].

The results showed that (1) our LSTM-based DRL training and testing environments achieved a mean square error of 0.0015 across 16 normalized AHU parameters when predicting AHU sensor readings, which suggests an accurate approximation of the AHU operations using our LSTM models, and (2) the AHUs controlled by the DRL agent in testing environments achieved a 27%–30% lower energy consumption in three months as compared to the existing rule-based control in the same building, while maintaining an average thermal comfort level at 10% predicted percentage of dissatisfaction (PPD) during working hours on weekdays, which falls in the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE) recommended comfort level of 5%–20% PPD.
3 Proposed framework We propose a DRL based HVAC control framework with the goal of minimizing energy consumption while maintaining thermal comfort levels for occupants.
The DRL agent's performance will be measured by the reward it received calculated using Equation (7), which takes into consideration of the energy consumption as well as thermal comfort levels.
Rewards received by the DRL agent were calculated using Equation (7), which had three tunable parameters (i.e., ψ , β , ω ) to balance the emphasis on energy consumption and thermal comfort.

The logic of selecting the possible values of the three parameters is twofold: 1) to guarantee that the DRL agent receives relatively the same amount of penalty for high energy consumption and high PPD during occupied hours; and 2) to ensure that the penalty of energy consumption during the unoccupied hours is similar to the combined penalty of energy consumption and PPD during the occupied hours.
Therefore, we identified the set of ( ψ , β , ω ) that results in the same reward for energy consumption and PPD from historical data, which is (5, 10, 2.0).

Note that the absolute value of the reward does not have any practical units, since it is a numerical representation of energy consumption and thermal comfort level solely determined by the reward design presented in Equation (7).

Deploying a non-convergent DRL agent to an AHU can result in sub-optimal actions such as turning the fan completely off during the day to avoid high energy consumption but disregard occupants’ thermal comfort levels.
If none of the parameter sets can achieve a convergent reward, the reward function needs to be redesigned to better balance energy consumption and thermal comfort levels.

selection framework for data-driven whole-building automated fault detection and diagnostics in commercial buildings Liang Zhang ∗ Stephen Frank Janghyun Kim Xin Jin Matt Leach National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, 80401, United States National Renewable Energy Laboratory Golden CO 80401 United States National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, 80401, United States ∗ Corresponding author.
The focus of this paper is on a data-driven whole-building AFDD model.
In general, no comprehensive methodology to guide feature extraction and selection in the development of a data-driven whole-building AFDD model has been presented in the literature to date.
Section 2 presents the systematic feature extraction and selection framework for data-driven whole-building AFDD.
2 Feature extraction and selection framework for whole-building AFDD The framework is designed to guide the feature engineering for data-driven whole-building AFDD algorithms.

The feature selection process in this study uses the similar framework in Zhang and Wen [21], which uses a hybrid method that combines filter method and wrapper method to decide the final feature set for a data-driven building energy model.

The focus of this paper is on a data-driven whole-building AFDD model.
The focus of this paper is on a data-driven whole-building AFDD model.
In general, no comprehensive methodology to guide feature extraction and selection in the development of a data-driven whole-building AFDD model has been presented in the literature to date.
In general, no comprehensive methodology to guide feature extraction and selection in the development of a data-driven whole-building AFDD model has been presented in the literature to date.
Section 2 presents the systematic feature extraction and selection framework for data-driven whole-building AFDD.
Section 2 presents the systematic feature extraction and selection framework for data-driven whole-building AFDD.
2 Feature extraction and selection framework for whole-building AFDD The framework is designed to guide the feature engineering for data-driven whole-building AFDD algorithms.
2 Feature extraction and selection framework for whole-building AFDD The framework is designed to guide the feature engineering for data-driven whole-building AFDD algorithms.

The feature selection process in this study uses the similar framework in Zhang and Wen [21], which uses a hybrid method that combines filter method and wrapper method to decide the final feature set for a data-driven building energy model.

The feature selection process in this study uses the similar framework in Zhang and Wen [21], which uses a hybrid method that combines filter method and wrapper method to decide the final feature set for a data-driven building energy model.

107338 S0360-1323(20)30707-1 10.1016/j.buildenv.2020.107338 Fig.

Feature selection techniques, including filter, wrapper, embedded, and hybrid methods, have been studied in AFDD for building HVAC systems such as AHU, VAV boxes, and chillers, as well as for whole-building AFDD.

The feature selection process in this study uses the similar framework in Zhang and Wen [21], which uses a hybrid method that combines filter method and wrapper method to decide the final feature set for a data-driven building energy model.

Feature selection techniques, including filter, wrapper, embedded, and hybrid methods, have been studied in AFDD for building HVAC systems such as AHU, VAV boxes, and chillers, as well as for whole-building AFDD.

Feature selection techniques, including filter, wrapper, embedded, and hybrid methods, have been studied in AFDD for building HVAC systems such as AHU, VAV boxes, and chillers, as well as for whole-building AFDD.

The feature selection process in this study uses the similar framework in Zhang and Wen [21], which uses a hybrid method that combines filter method and wrapper method to decide the final feature set for a data-driven building energy model.

107338 S0360-1323(20)30707-1 10.1016/j.buildenv.2020.107338 Fig.

Feature selection techniques, including filter, wrapper, embedded, and hybrid methods, have been studied in AFDD for building HVAC systems such as AHU, VAV boxes, and chillers, as well as for whole-building AFDD.

The feature selection process in this study uses the similar framework in Zhang and Wen [21], which uses a hybrid method that combines filter method and wrapper method to decide the final feature set for a data-driven building energy model.

selection framework for data-driven whole-building automated fault detection and diagnostics in commercial buildings Liang Zhang ∗ Stephen Frank Janghyun Kim Xin Jin Matt Leach National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, 80401, United States National Renewable Energy Laboratory Golden CO 80401 United States National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, 80401, United States ∗ Corresponding author.

Keywords Automated fault detection and diagnostics Whole-building AFDD Statistical feature extraction Feature selection Feature engineering Commercial building 1 Introduction Equipment faults and control errors are pervasive in today's commercial buildings [1].
The focus of this paper is on a data-driven whole-building AFDD model.

Feature selection techniques, including filter, wrapper, embedded, and hybrid methods, have been studied in AFDD for building HVAC systems such as AHU, VAV boxes, and chillers, as well as for whole-building AFDD.

To sum up the above literature review about feature extraction and feature selection in whole-building AFDD, compared with other feature extraction categories, statistical feature extraction is the most widely-used and straightforward method for dealing with high-dimensional sensor data.

However, many researchers use statistical feature extraction with limited statistics and large window size, ignoring the different duration and symptoms of abnormality of various faults in whole-building AFDD.
In general, no comprehensive methodology to guide feature extraction and selection in the development of a data-driven whole-building AFDD model has been presented in the literature to date.
Section 2 presents the systematic feature extraction and selection framework for data-driven whole-building AFDD.
2 Feature extraction and selection framework for whole-building AFDD The framework is designed to guide the feature engineering for data-driven whole-building AFDD algorithms.

The feature selection process in this study uses the similar framework in Zhang and Wen [21], which uses a hybrid method that combines filter method and wrapper method to decide the final feature set for a data-driven building energy model.
[4], while the virtual testbed is a whole-building energy model of Oak Ridge National Laboratory's two-story Flexible Research Platform (FRP) facility.

statistical: Keywords Automated fault detection and diagnostics Whole-building AFDD Statistical feature extraction Feature selection Feature engineering Commercial building 1 Introduction Equipment faults and control errors are pervasive in today's commercial buildings [1].

To sum up the above literature review about feature extraction and feature selection in whole-building AFDD, compared with other feature extraction categories, statistical feature extraction is the most widely-used and straightforward method for dealing with high-dimensional sensor data.

However, many researchers use statistical feature extraction with limited statistics and large window size, ignoring the different duration and symptoms of abnormality of various faults in whole-building AFDD.
oak: [4], while the virtual testbed is a whole-building energy model of Oak Ridge National Laboratory's two-story Flexible Research Platform (FRP) facility.

3 Case study To validate the developed feature extraction and selection framework, we applied it to a whole-building AFDD algorithm using a virtual testbed.
The algorithm is a variation of the whole-building AFDD approach presented in Frank et al.

In other words, accounting for personal comfort in a centrally controlled HVAC system, resulted in increased energy use with no guarantee of satisfactory indoor conditions for all occupants.
The results of simulations were interpreted in terms of effective energy use for thermal comfort provision.

online_learning_evidence: These methodologies promote context-aware adaptive control strategies, in which HVAC systems operate according to the contextual needs.
The outcome of these methods is the creation of personal comfort models [5,55] that could be used to optimize the temperature setpoints in real-time operations.

3 Adaptive operation assessment methodology 3.1 Control strategy The premise of this study centers on evaluating adaptive control frameworks in indoor environments, and thus, the methodology is based on simulated scenarios of operations in a surrogate model of a thermal zone and the associated energy efficiency implications.

online_learning_evidence: Furthermore, at large scales, MPC like many other advanced model-based techniques may require formidable computational power if a real-time (or near real-time) solution is required [11].
The time-intensive process of data collection makes the online training of the RL algorithms so long that it practically becomes impossible to have a plug & play RL-based controller for HVAC systems.
Reducing the system’s dimension, if possible, is another way to shorten the online training period.

online_learning_evidence: Such complex models are not suitable for MPC, which involves real-time optimization.

As mentioned earlier, one of the main challenges of including humidity and latent heat is the need for a cooling and dehumidifying coil model that is simple enough to be used in real-time optimization and yet accurate enough to lead to useful results.
[30] provides a comprehensive MPC framework which uses real-time building energy management system data.
Lastly, a nondeterministic optimization algorithm (genetic algorithm) is used to perform the minimization which is challenging to use for real-time control.
The proposed SL-MPC controller needs real-time measurements of zone temperature and humidity, while the S-MPC and BL controllers need real-time measurements of zone temperature alone.

Hence, to resolve this problem, we developed a method for an efficient Bayesian model update.
It is worth noting that this method can also be used in other Bayesian model estimation problems where an efficient model update is needed.
In such long experiments or implementations, techniques to deal with the change in occupants' thermal comfort, e.g., online learning or having time related input variables, would be required.
Appendix B Bayesian model update with sequential Monte Carlo Let us suppose that we already estimated the posterior parameter distribution given some data, D .

Appendix C Computation of the expected Kullback–Leibler divergence We want to compute (C-1) U ( t new , r new ) = E y [ D K L ( p ( θ | D , d new ) | | p ( θ | D ) ) ] = ∫ ∑ y new = − 1 2 p ( θ | D , d new ) p ( y new | D , t new , r new ) log p ( θ | D , d new ) p ( θ | D ) d θ We can rewrite the above equation as: (C-2) U ( t new , r new ) = ∫ ∑ y new = − 1 2 p ( y new | θ , t new , r new ) p ( θ | D ) log p ( y new | θ , t new , r new ) p ( y new | D , t new , r new ) d θ (C-3) p ( θ | D , d new ) = p ( y new | θ , t new , r new ) p ( θ | D ) p ( y new | D , t new , r new ) Since we have the samples representing p ( θ | D ) , we can calculate the quantity using Monte Carlo integration as: (C-4) 1 N ∑ i = 1 N ∑ y new = − 1 2 p ( y new | θ i , t new , r new ) log p ( y new | θ i , t new , r new ) p ( y new | D , t new , r new ) We can compute p ( y new | D , t new , r new ) , which corresponds to p ( D new | D ) in Appendix B, easily through the process of the Bayesian model update with sequential Monte Carlo.

energy_use|thermal_comfort: Occupancy-based heating control is important for not only achieving thermal comfort but also reducing the heating energy consumption of residential buildings.

3.2.2 Optimization of the start and stop times Because the parameters of the optimal start and stop times can affect the heating energy consumption and thermal comfort, the optimal parameter values to minimize the heating energy consumption and thermal discomfort were investigated.
Alternative 3 is suitable if thermal comfort is prioritized regardless of the heating energy consumption.

showed that applying a pre-smoothed CO2 concentration in an office space can enhance the real-time estimation of indoor occupants to an accuracy of up to 94% [29].

In addition, further studies should be conducted to embed the parametric simulation tool in the commercial controller in order to apply the optimal start and stop control to the real-time heating system controls.
In this step, the average departure and arrival times need to be updated every day in order to apply the daily variation of occupancy schedule to the real-time control of heating system.

[105] MPC/NARX temperature experiment 30.95 % savings in energy costs [106] MPC PMV-PPD experiment NA [107] MPC temperature range simulation 17 % reductions in energy use The use of artificial intelligence (AI) methods in the prediction of thermal comfort in buildings: energy implications of AI-based thermal comfort controls Jack Ngarambe a Geun Young Yun a ⁎ Mat Santamouris a b a Department of Architectural Engineering, Kyung Hee University, 1732, Deogyeong-daero, Giheung-gu, Yongin-si, Gyeonggi-do17104, South Korea Department of Architectural Engineering Kyung Hee University, 1732, Deogyeong-daero, Giheung-gu Yongin-si Gyeonggi-do 17104 South Korea aDepartment of Architectural Engineering, Kyung Hee University, 1732, Deogyeong-daero, Giheung-gu, Yongin-si, Gyeonggi-do17104, South Korea b Faculty of Built Environment, University of New South Wales, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia Faculty of Built Environment University of New South Wales Sydney New South Wales Australia bFaculty of Built Environment, University of New South Wales, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia ⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Architectural Engineering, Kyung Hee University, 1732, Deogyeong-daero, Giheung-gu, Yongin-si, Gyeonggi-do17104, South Korea Department of Architectural Engineering Kyung Hee University 1732, Deogyeong-daero, Giheung-gu Yongin-si Gyeonggi-do 17104 South Korea Buildings consume about 40 % of globally-produced energy.
However, striking a balance between reducing building energy use and providing adequate comfort levels is a significant challenge.
Consequently, a key goal in the building service industry is achieving sufficient thermal comfort levels while minimizing energy consumption.
As such, conventional control practices tend to be non-optimal in regards to both energy consumption and the provision of thermal comfort.

By using such devices for data collection, it would be interesting to see how (i) the current use of advanced analytical methods for the modeling and control of thermal comfort extend to residential buildings, in particular to sleeping occupants, and (ii) the subsequent implications of using these methods in regards to occupant satisfaction and building energy use.

For example, through ML technologies, designers should be able to explore which physical or non-physical elements are likely to result in occupant discomfort and how they can be properly controlled to provide thermally comfortable conditions while minimizing energy use.

While there is strong theoretical evidence regarding the potential usefulness of artificial intelligence-based predictive modeling on occupant thermal comfort and the associated building energy benefits, there is a lack of field and experimental studies to quantify the benefits of AI-based methods over traditional building control methods in terms of both thermal comfort and building energy use.

We have discussed several approaches that we believe can help in the integration of AI into buildings; these could potentially result in the provision of adequate comfort levels while minimizing energy use.

online_learning_evidence: Atthajaryakul and Leephakpreeda [44] computed the PMV index in real-time using a feed-forward ANN and reported good agreement between the occupant thermal comfort levels calculated using the developed ANN model and those calculated using the conventional PMV model.

They noted that the advantages of using such deep learning models to compute the PMV index over traditional methods were a reduction in the number of sensors required and the ability to control HVAC systems in real-time based on occupant thermal comfort.

The resulting detailed MPC calculations and workflow are complicated and unreliable for large scale implementation by practitioners and are the motivation for developing a simpler rule extraction approach.

online_learning_evidence: Few mechanically ventilated facilities demonstrate the control and measurement capability to implement real-time MPC and validate the energy use of multiple thermal zones.
Reactive control and MPC have some inherent deadbands due to PI (proportional integrating) loops and real-time optimization computational delays respectively.

whitebox: The contribution of this paper is of four-folds: 1) the energy saving strategy is divided into system model construction and air balancing control; 2) a data-driven framework of modeling multi-zone demand controlled ventilation system is proposed; 3) the operating positions of each damper are resolved with empirical formula of damper; 4) the effectiveness of the proposed data-driven approach for saving energy of a multi-zone demand controlled ventilation system is validated through an experimental apparatus.
data-driven: The contribution of this paper is of four-folds: 1) the energy saving strategy is divided into system model construction and air balancing control; 2) a data-driven framework of modeling multi-zone demand controlled ventilation system is proposed; 3) the operating positions of each damper are resolved with empirical formula of damper; 4) the effectiveness of the proposed data-driven approach for saving energy of a multi-zone demand controlled ventilation system is validated through an experimental apparatus.

Control sequences for air distribution and terminal systems in heating, ventilating, and air-conditioning (HVAC) aim to achieve a balance in the system outputs, i.e., maintain thermal comfort and indoor air quality (IAQ) with minimal energy use.

We developed the virtual model using the equation-based Modelica language for its ability to simulate complex physical systems, and applied Monte Carlo simulations to evaluate the impact of uncertainty on annual performance for system outputs of thermal comfort, represented by zone air temperature and relative humidity (RH); indoor air quality (IAQ), represented by carbon dioxide (CO2) concentration; and energy use.

Although the degradation in accuracy level resulted in a small improvement in thermal comfort and IAQ as discussed with regard to result 2, the degradation in accuracy level resulted in an increase in site electricity use as expected.

whitebox: To evaluate the effects of uncertainty in HVAC systems with advanced sequences of operation, this work applies a Monte Carlo uncertainty analysis to a detailed Modelica building energy model that has been programmed with G36 control sequences.

The building thermal model with detailed implementation of G36 sequences of operation were integrated with uncertainty models at small time-scales to simulate realistic performance of advanced control sequences in handling uncertainty.
modelica: To evaluate the effects of uncertainty in HVAC systems with advanced sequences of operation, this work applies a Monte Carlo uncertainty analysis to a detailed Modelica building energy model that has been programmed with G36 control sequences.
simulate: The building thermal model with detailed implementation of G36 sequences of operation were integrated with uncertainty models at small time-scales to simulate realistic performance of advanced control sequences in handling uncertainty.
greybox: The building thermal model with detailed implementation of G36 sequences of operation were integrated with uncertainty models at small time-scales to simulate realistic performance of advanced control sequences in handling uncertainty.

1.2 Objectives In this work we developed a building energy model with a detailed implementation for the control sequence of operation described by G36 integrated with uncertainty models at small time scales.
integrated: The building thermal model with detailed implementation of G36 sequences of operation were integrated with uncertainty models at small time-scales to simulate realistic performance of advanced control sequences in handling uncertainty.

4.1 Day-ahead-based optimization formulation for BEM To be a participant of the day-ahead market, the objectives of the BEM are 1) minimizing building day-ahead energy consumption cost, and 2) satisfying the comfort requirements of building occupants, such as zone temperature, airflow, humidity, and luminosity.
The goal of the optimization problem is to minimize building electricity costs and reduce the overall building energy consumption during peak load hours while satisfying human comfort demand.

The simulation model is also used to test and evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed machine-learning model and the iterative optimization algorithm and the improvement of building energy management in terms of energy consumption efficiency, cost saving, and satisfaction of human comfort.

Keywords Building energy management Demand response Multi-thermal zones Artificial neural network Heating ventilation and air conditioning Particle swarm optimization Nomenclature Abbreviations DR demand response BEM building energy management HVAC heating ventilation and air conditioning VAV variable air volume IHG internal heat gain MILP mixed-integer linear programming PSO particle swarm optimization FL fixed load DL deferrable load RL regulatable load NN neural network DAP day ahead price AHU air handling unit Variables P electric energy, k W h C specific heat, J / k g ⋅ C ∘ θ deferrable loads workload parameter T temperature, C ∘ Q heat energy, J m ˙ air mass flow rate, k g / s Parameters A lighting area, m 2 η luminous efficacy, l m / W c utilization factor M maintenance factor R the equivalent thermal resistance, K ⋅ m 2 / W E v illuminance, lux f u IHG load usage factor f s IHG load operating factor C L F t cooling load factor Subscripts j number of an exterior wall, roof or window of a zone t time slot k number of an interior wall or floor of a zone z building thermal zone number Superscripts D L _ t o t a l total deferrable loads l i g h t lighting system o d outdoor n z neighboring zone 1 Introduction Building energy in the United States represents a dominant portion of total U.S. electric energy consumption [1].

Overall, the major innovations of the paper are as follows: 1) A machine-learning-based model for the HVAC of a multi-thermal-zone building, which can better reflect and capture the actual building thermal behavior, 2) A special data preprocessing strategy by considering HVAC running mode and standby mode so as to improve machine-learning efficiency, 3) A consideration of IHG loads into the development of the HVAC learning model which increases the learned HVAC model accuracy, 4) A development of optimal BEM considering marketed-based DR, 5) A strategy to solve the optimization problem through MILP for building energy components with physical-based models (i.e., IHG loads) and through PSO for building energy components with learning-based models (i.e., HVAC system), 6) An iterative strategy to solve the coupled MILP and PSO optimization problems, 7) A consideration of human comfort demands into learning-based BEM optimization.
The CityLearn initiative uses a reinforcement learning mechanism to determine the BEM policy directly.
It is necessary to point out that the NN just saw the data and did not know any information about the building model.
The proposed smart building BEM is evaluated based on testing data sets that are not used in training the initial NN.

This paper presents a novel intelligent BEM system for multi-thermal-zone buildings considering market-based DR, which combines a building control center, building loads (including non-HVAC loads and HVAC loads), and an iterative optimization routine for the BEM development.

Overall, the major innovations of the paper are as follows: 1) A machine-learning-based model for the HVAC of a multi-thermal-zone building, which can better reflect and capture the actual building thermal behavior, 2) A special data preprocessing strategy by considering HVAC running mode and standby mode so as to improve machine-learning efficiency, 3) A consideration of IHG loads into the development of the HVAC learning model which increases the learned HVAC model accuracy, 4) A development of optimal BEM considering marketed-based DR, 5) A strategy to solve the optimization problem through MILP for building energy components with physical-based models (i.e., IHG loads) and through PSO for building energy components with learning-based models (i.e., HVAC system), 6) An iterative strategy to solve the coupled MILP and PSO optimization problems, 7) A consideration of human comfort demands into learning-based BEM optimization.

3.2 Training NN to extract building HVAC model In order to have the updated building HVAC model corresponding to a recent weather condition, the NN is trained at the end of each day as new training data is collected and saved into the data storage.
The data sequence, containing building operation data and weather data of the past two to three weeks saved in the data storage, is used to train the NN to get the NN-based HVAC system model.
The generated data from the simulation was then used to train the NN to gain the HVAC model.

The paper proposes an intelligent learning strategy based on an NN to extract actual building HVAC model from measured data, which can accurately reflect the performance of a real-life and complex building HVAC system.

This paper presents a novel intelligent BEM system for multi-thermal-zone buildings considering market-based DR, which combines a building control center, building loads (including non-HVAC loads and HVAC loads), and an iterative optimization routine for the BEM development.

Overall, the major innovations of the paper are as follows: 1) A machine-learning-based model for the HVAC of a multi-thermal-zone building, which can better reflect and capture the actual building thermal behavior, 2) A special data preprocessing strategy by considering HVAC running mode and standby mode so as to improve machine-learning efficiency, 3) A consideration of IHG loads into the development of the HVAC learning model which increases the learned HVAC model accuracy, 4) A development of optimal BEM considering marketed-based DR, 5) A strategy to solve the optimization problem through MILP for building energy components with physical-based models (i.e., IHG loads) and through PSO for building energy components with learning-based models (i.e., HVAC system), 6) An iterative strategy to solve the coupled MILP and PSO optimization problems, 7) A consideration of human comfort demands into learning-based BEM optimization.
Overall, the purpose of such a design strategy is to be able to get an optimal BEM solution quickly and efficiently.

4.1 Day-ahead-based optimization formulation for BEM To be a participant of the day-ahead market, the objectives of the BEM are 1) minimizing building day-ahead energy consumption cost, and 2) satisfying the comfort requirements of building occupants, such as zone temperature, airflow, humidity, and luminosity.

4.2 Procedure and algorithms for solving the BEM optimization problem Based on the iterative optimization strategy presented in Section 4.1, the following procedure is developed to solve the BEM optimization problem.

Then, the learned HVAC system model is applied to determine the optimal BEM control action for the building operation on the next day through the iterative optimization strategy discussed in Sections 4.1 and 4.2.
Thus, an optimization technique is needed in order to generate an optimal BEM policy.

Some major differences between the proposed approach and the CityLearn initiative include: 1) The proposed approach is a supervised learning approach to get the HVAC model that is then used in an optimization algorithm to generate an optimal BEM policy.

Compared with results without using the proposed BEM, the proposed BEM can achieve an energy saving of 12.94% for deferrable loads and lighting system, total building energy saving of 19.09%, and total cost saving of 30.72%.

The learned HVAC model is then used to develop a learning-based, optimal BEM system, which includes a novel iterative optimization strategy to obtain optimal BEM for a building consisting of all the three types of loads.

For commercial buildings, the main objective of Building Energy Management (BEM) is to minimize the energy consumption cost while assuring the safety and reliability of the building operation [10].
A day-ahead, multi-objective optimization model for the BEM under a time-based-rate DR is proposed in Ref.
[14], which can achieve up to 15% reduction in energy cost in comparison to the BEM focused just on one building.

This paper presents a novel intelligent BEM system for multi-thermal-zone buildings considering market-based DR, which combines a building control center, building loads (including non-HVAC loads and HVAC loads), and an iterative optimization routine for the BEM development.
For BEM considering the day-ahead electric power market, the day-ahead electricity price and weather data are achieved from the electric utility companies and national weather services.
BEM has great potential to contribute to the day-ahead market of electric utilities, which is the focus of this paper.

4.1 Day-ahead-based optimization formulation for BEM To be a participant of the day-ahead market, the objectives of the BEM are 1) minimizing building day-ahead energy consumption cost, and 2) satisfying the comfort requirements of building occupants, such as zone temperature, airflow, humidity, and luminosity.

First, the aim of the BEM is to minimize the total building day-ahead energy cost C b l d while considering various penalty factors related to customers demands as shown by: (12) M i n ∑ t N T ∑ z N Z p t D A P ⋅ ( P t , z F L + P t , z D L + P t , z R L ) + ∑ t N T ∑ z N Z p t , z d p ⋅ θ t , z + ∑ t N T ∑ z N Z p t , z l p ⋅ ( E t , z l i g h t − E b e s t ) 2 + ∑ t N T ∑ z N Z p t , z t p ⋅ Δ T t , z t p where objective function consists of the following cost items: 1) total building energy cost, 2) overload penalty cost of DLs, 3) a visual discomfort penalty cost, and 4) a thermal discomfort penalty cost.

Compared with results without using the proposed BEM, the proposed BEM can achieve an energy saving of 12.94% for deferrable loads and lighting system, total building energy saving of 19.09%, and total cost saving of 30.72%.

Keywords Building energy management Demand response Multi-thermal zones Artificial neural network Heating ventilation and air conditioning Particle swarm optimization Nomenclature Abbreviations DR demand response BEM building energy management HVAC heating ventilation and air conditioning VAV variable air volume IHG internal heat gain MILP mixed-integer linear programming PSO particle swarm optimization FL fixed load DL deferrable load RL regulatable load NN neural network DAP day ahead price AHU air handling unit Variables P electric energy, k W h C specific heat, J / k g ⋅ C ∘ θ deferrable loads workload parameter T temperature, C ∘ Q heat energy, J m ˙ air mass flow rate, k g / s Parameters A lighting area, m 2 η luminous efficacy, l m / W c utilization factor M maintenance factor R the equivalent thermal resistance, K ⋅ m 2 / W E v illuminance, lux f u IHG load usage factor f s IHG load operating factor C L F t cooling load factor Subscripts j number of an exterior wall, roof or window of a zone t time slot k number of an interior wall or floor of a zone z building thermal zone number Superscripts D L _ t o t a l total deferrable loads l i g h t lighting system o d outdoor n z neighboring zone 1 Introduction Building energy in the United States represents a dominant portion of total U.S. electric energy consumption [1].
Different DR methods have been developed for the energy management of residential homes [6–9].
A day-ahead, multi-objective optimization model for the BEM under a time-based-rate DR is proposed in Ref.
[13], plug-in hybrid electric vehicles are included in BEM to improve the power supply reliability and flexibility for building energy and comfort management.

This paper presents a novel intelligent BEM system for multi-thermal-zone buildings considering market-based DR, which combines a building control center, building loads (including non-HVAC loads and HVAC loads), and an iterative optimization routine for the BEM development.

Overall, the major innovations of the paper are as follows: 1) A machine-learning-based model for the HVAC of a multi-thermal-zone building, which can better reflect and capture the actual building thermal behavior, 2) A special data preprocessing strategy by considering HVAC running mode and standby mode so as to improve machine-learning efficiency, 3) A consideration of IHG loads into the development of the HVAC learning model which increases the learned HVAC model accuracy, 4) A development of optimal BEM considering marketed-based DR, 5) A strategy to solve the optimization problem through MILP for building energy components with physical-based models (i.e., IHG loads) and through PSO for building energy components with learning-based models (i.e., HVAC system), 6) An iterative strategy to solve the coupled MILP and PSO optimization problems, 7) A consideration of human comfort demands into learning-based BEM optimization.
The simulation study illustrates that the learning-based HVAC model can accurately capture the actual building HVAC energy consumption behavior and be applied to optimal DR-based BEM service.

online_learning_evidence: Market-based DR uses the electricity market day-ahead or real-time price to affect customers to rearrange their energy consumption to satisfy the grid need.
4 Optimal building energy management The typical electricity markets include: day-ahead and real-time electricity markets.
The real-time market lets market participants buy or sell wholesale electricity during the course of the operating day.
Typically, it is expected 80%–85% of the energy demand to be settled via the day-ahead market while the rest to be adjusted via the real-time market depending on the real-time load outages.

energy_use|thermal_comfort: The results indicate that with non-linear power and PMV calculations, the MPC controller could perform much better in terms of both the energy consumption and indoor thermal comfort.
The MPC control in this case would export the minimal energy consumption as long as the solution sits within the constraint range of the PMV.

The second J 2 , maximum thermal comfort strategy, is the thermal comfort-oriented equation, and the system would act to manipulate the PMV value as close to nil as possible without the consideration of the energy consumption.
J 1 and J 3 contributes to efficiencies lower than best thermal comfort strategy( J 2 ), which failed to achieve high performance on neither thermal comfort nor energy consumption.
Thus, with the disturbance, the strategy 6 remains the most optimal control strategy balancing both the indoor thermal comfort and energy consumption.
The results indicate that with non-linear power and PMV calculations, the MPC controller could perform much better in terms of both the energy consumption and indoor thermal comfort.
The MPC control in this case would export the minimal energy consumption as long as the solution sits within the constraint range of the PMV.

The second J 2 , maximum thermal comfort strategy, is the thermal comfort-oriented equation, and the system would act to manipulate the PMV value as close to nil as possible without the consideration of the energy consumption.
J 1 and J 3 contributes to efficiencies lower than best thermal comfort strategy( J 2 ), which failed to achieve high performance on neither thermal comfort nor energy consumption.
Thus, with the disturbance, the strategy 6 remains the most optimal control strategy balancing both the indoor thermal comfort and energy consumption.

energy_use|thermal_comfort: The BEMS is centrally controlled by the MPC which performs a multi-variable optimization, with a single objective function, to efficiently manage the renewable energy usage, charging and discharging of the battery and heating load distribution to maintain the indoor operative temperature within given comfort bounds with a reduced heating energy consumption.

The BEMS is centrally controlled by the MPC which performs a multi-variable optimization, with a single objective function, to efficiently manage the renewable energy usage, charging and discharging of the battery and heating load distribution to maintain the indoor operative temperature within given comfort bounds with a reduced heating energy consumption.

greybox: A novel implementation strategy of a centralized model predictive control (MPC) is proposed for a zone based comfort and energy management in a residential building.
A TRNSYS-MATLAB co-simulation is used for this comfort and energy management case studies.

A simple case of MPC optimization for comfort management (without any BEMS control) is also simulated in TRNSYS as a reference to estimate the benefit of the centralized MPC controlled comfort and energy management system.
9 Conclusion In an effort to design a centralized system to control different components of the HVAC and BEMS systems simultaneously, a novel predictive control strategy is proposed in this article.
We convey our sincere thanks to Mr. Justin Tamasauskas from CanmetENERGY, NRCan, Varennes, for his contributions in developing the TRNSYS building model.

A novel implementation strategy of a centralized model predictive control (MPC) is proposed for a zone based comfort and energy management in a residential building.
Another MPC based strategy for hygrothermal comfort and energy management in an office building is presented in Ref.

In this article, the contribution is focused on the performance of the MPC in an amalgamated comfort and energy management optimization scenario, hence the base case presented in this study has an MPC driven comfort and energy cost optimization with a rule based control for the energy management.

The BEMS is centrally controlled by the MPC which performs a multi-variable optimization, with a single objective function, to efficiently manage the renewable energy usage, charging and discharging of the battery and heating load distribution to maintain the indoor operative temperature within given comfort bounds with a reduced heating energy consumption.

The proposed approach contributes in combining two major building control engineering research focuses, namely the HVAC control for comfort management with low operative cost and energy management for building electricity consumption.
A TRNSYS-MATLAB co-simulation is used for this comfort and energy management case studies.
7.1 Base case scenario An MPC controlled comfort management system is considered in the base case scenario along with a rule based energy management strategy described in the flowchart in Fig.
In Case I, the simultaneous comfort and BEMS MPC optimization achieve a 13.5% reduction in the energy cost as compared to the base case.

A simple case of MPC optimization for comfort management (without any BEMS control) is also simulated in TRNSYS as a reference to estimate the benefit of the centralized MPC controlled comfort and energy management system.

The MPC controlled comfort and energy management system uses the PV generated solar energy to supply close to 10% of the total heating demand of the house, thereby saving approximately 198 gCO2 emission daily, considering 32 gCO2/kWh GHG emission factor for Ontario [15].

In this article, the contribution is focused on the performance of the MPC in an amalgamated comfort and energy management optimization scenario, hence the base case presented in this study has an MPC driven comfort and energy cost optimization with a rule based control for the energy management.

The BEMS is centrally controlled by the MPC which performs a multi-variable optimization, with a single objective function, to efficiently manage the renewable energy usage, charging and discharging of the battery and heating load distribution to maintain the indoor operative temperature within given comfort bounds with a reduced heating energy consumption.
The base case scenario includes an MPC controlled heating system and a rule based energy management system.
7.1 Base case scenario An MPC controlled comfort management system is considered in the base case scenario along with a rule based energy management strategy described in the flowchart in Fig.
In Case I, the simultaneous comfort and BEMS MPC optimization achieve a 13.5% reduction in the energy cost as compared to the base case.

A simple case of MPC optimization for comfort management (without any BEMS control) is also simulated in TRNSYS as a reference to estimate the benefit of the centralized MPC controlled comfort and energy management system.

energy_use|thermal_comfort: The case study results reveal that at both set-point intervals the energy consumption in low comfort zones (i.e., zones 4 and 5) is significantly lower than in the moderate and high comfort zones following high-temperature variations in these zones.

The case study results reveal that at both set-point intervals the energy consumption in low comfort zones (i.e., zones 4 and 5) is significantly lower than in the moderate and high comfort zones following high-temperature variations in these zones.

whitebox: The optimization problem for the proposed PBDR control strategy is formulated using a building’s thermal model and an occupant’s thermal preferences model, and simulation results are obtained using MATLAB/Simulink tool.
matlab: The optimization problem for the proposed PBDR control strategy is formulated using a building’s thermal model and an occupant’s thermal preferences model, and simulation results are obtained using MATLAB/Simulink tool.
simulink: The optimization problem for the proposed PBDR control strategy is formulated using a building’s thermal model and an occupant’s thermal preferences model, and simulation results are obtained using MATLAB/Simulink tool.
