whitebox: 2.2 Chiller model In the literature, comprehensive and complex chiller models are available (Wang et al., 2004; Lu et al., 2005) but these models are not control-oriented.

This paper considers a simple control-oriented chiller model (Nassif et al., 2004; Radhakrishnan et al., 2015): (4) P t c = ϕ ∑ q z ( t ) η C O P + ( 1 − ϕ ) q t η C O P where P t c is the total power consumed by the chiller in kW that is used to generate the chilled water consumed by the cooling coil for all zones, q t is the total load of the building in kW, ϕ ⇒ [ 0,1 ] is the damper position, ƞ is the chiller efficiency factor and COP is the chiller coefficient of performance.
control-oriented: 2.2 Chiller model In the literature, comprehensive and complex chiller models are available (Wang et al., 2004; Lu et al., 2005) but these models are not control-oriented.
2.2 Chiller model In the literature, comprehensive and complex chiller models are available (Wang et al., 2004; Lu et al., 2005) but these models are not control-oriented.

This paper considers a simple control-oriented chiller model (Nassif et al., 2004; Radhakrishnan et al., 2015): (4) P t c = ϕ ∑ q z ( t ) η C O P + ( 1 − ϕ ) q t η C O P where P t c is the total power consumed by the chiller in kW that is used to generate the chilled water consumed by the cooling coil for all zones, q t is the total load of the building in kW, ϕ ⇒ [ 0,1 ] is the damper position, ƞ is the chiller efficiency factor and COP is the chiller coefficient of performance.

This paper considers a simple control-oriented chiller model (Nassif et al., 2004; Radhakrishnan et al., 2015): (4) P t c = ϕ ∑ q z ( t ) η C O P + ( 1 − ϕ ) q t η C O P where P t c is the total power consumed by the chiller in kW that is used to generate the chilled water consumed by the cooling coil for all zones, q t is the total load of the building in kW, ϕ ⇒ [ 0,1 ] is the damper position, ƞ is the chiller efficiency factor and COP is the chiller coefficient of performance.

This paper considers a simple control-oriented chiller model (Nassif et al., 2004; Radhakrishnan et al., 2015): (4) P t c = ϕ ∑ q z ( t ) η C O P + ( 1 − ϕ ) q t η C O P where P t c is the total power consumed by the chiller in kW that is used to generate the chilled water consumed by the cooling coil for all zones, q t is the total load of the building in kW, ϕ ⇒ [ 0,1 ] is the damper position, ƞ is the chiller efficiency factor and COP is the chiller coefficient of performance.

optimal_control: The optimization problem for the proposed PBDR control strategy is formulated using a building’s thermal model and an occupant’s thermal preferences model, and simulation results are obtained using MATLAB/Simulink tool.
cost: In (Abdulaal and Asfour, 2016) a control strategy has been proposed for aggregation and coordination of industrial and commercial loads for DR using RTP.
demand_response: In (Abdulaal and Asfour, 2016) a control strategy has been proposed for aggregation and coordination of industrial and commercial loads for DR using RTP.
Finn Implementation of demand response strategies in a multi-purpose commercial building using a whole-building simulation model approach Energy Build.

131 2016 76 86 D. Christantoni, S. Oxizidis, D. Flynn, and D. P. Finn, "Implementation of demand response strategies in a multi-purpose commercial building using a whole-building simulation model approach," Energy and Buildings, vol.

Previous thermostat controllers (Biyik et al., 2014; Ciabattoni et al., 2015; Ferreira et al., 2012) do not have an HVAC model and thus these controllers cannot calculate how much electricity was consumed by HVAC nor evaluate whether the load was curtailed during off-peak/peak periods compared to normal operation.

online_learning_evidence: This paper proposes an intelligent and new PBDR control strategy for multizone office buildings fed from renewable energy sources (RESs) and/or utility grid to optimize the HVAC operation considering the varying thermal preferences of occupants in various zones as a response of real-time pricing (RTP) signals.

Introduction 1.1 Motivation Commercial buildings’ electricity consumption is about 26% of the aggregated consumption in Sydney, Australia.
Time of use, real-time pricing (RTP) and critical peak pricing are different pricing mechanisms used for the DR program (Hao et al., 2017; Zhang et al., 2016).

Though (Kim, 2018) considers the electricity pricing for HVAC control, it uses the ratio of weighted coefficients for occupants’ thermal discomfort and the average price of electricity to trigger HVAC set-point temperature which is not suitable for high variations of electricity prices in the real-time market.

Contrasting, numerical analysis demonstrates that the proposed strategy is effective to reduce the peak load and enable the utility providers to adopt effective demand management using real-time pricing.

• The work in (Kim, 2018) uses the ratio of weighted coefficients for occupants’ thermal discomfort and the average price of electricity to trigger HVAC set-point temperature change in comparison to the current electricity price at time t. However, using this ratio as a trigger is not suitable for high variations of electricity prices in the real-time market.
To coin the real-time wholesale price structure for the retail market the authors in (Fernandez et al., 2018) design the real-time retail price.
Based on this, the half-hour ahead forecasts wholesale energy settlement price is considered as the real-time retail price of electricity in this paper.
However, using an average price or a constant threshold price is not suitable for high fluctuations in the retail price in the real-time market.

• The work in (Kim, 2018) uses the ratio of weighted coefficients for occupants’ thermal discomfort and the average price of electricity to trigger HVAC set-point temperature change in comparison to the current electricity price at time t. However, using this ratio as a trigger is not suitable for high variations of electricity prices in the real-time market.

Contrasting, the numerical results of this paper reported in Table 3 demonstrate that the proposed strategy is effective to reduce the peak load varies from 7.19 to 26.8% contingent on occupant’s thermal preferences, and thus enable the utility providers to adopt effective demand management using real-time pricing.

7 Conclusion In this paper, an easily deployable and improved PBDR control strategy in a real-time environment was is proposed to control a multi-zone office building HVAC load while considering the varying thermal comfort preferences of occupants.

For utilities and RESs integrated building operators, a real-time wholesale price based tariff is effective to reduce the peak load, the overall electricity consumption, and energy imbalance management.

Another direction could be recording the number of occupants in real-time for instantaneous load calculation if a large number of occupants shared one room/commonplace while considering the dynamic comfort preferences in a zone.
